p.text: Civil Procedure Act 2005 No 28 was assented to on 1 June 2005. Sections 8, 17 and Sch 2 commenced on 24 June 2005 (Gaz No 77 of 24 June 2005 p 2952). The remainder of the Act (except Sch 5.3[1]–[3], 5.15[4], 5.17[3], 5.30[8]) commenced on 15 August 2005 (Gaz No 100 of 10 August 2005, p 4205). Schedules 5.3[1]-[3], 5.15[4], 5.17[3], 5.30[8] commenced on 19 October 2005 (see commencement Proclamation for the Legal Profession Act 2004 in Gaz No 105, 19 August 2005 p 4570)

p.text: This Act is the Civil Procedure Act 2005.
This Act commences on a day or days to be appointed by proclamation, subject to this section.
Schedule 5.3[1], [2] and [3], 5.15[4], 5.17[3] and 5.30[8] commence on the commencement of section 3, or on the commencement of Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004, whichever is the later.
Schedule 5.3[4] commences on the commencement of section 9.
Schedule 5.43 and 5.44 commence on the commencement of section 18.
Different days may be appointed for the commencement of a single provision of Schedule 4 or 5 for the purpose of commencing the repeals or amendments effected by the provision on different days.
In this Act:
[def rep Act 1 of 2013 Sch 1 item 1.6[1], effective 28 February 2013]
means any proceedings other than criminal proceedings.
includes:
a claim for possession of land, and
a claim for delivery of goods, and
a claim for the recovery of damages or other money, and
a claim for a declaration of right, and
a claim for the determination of any question or matter that may be determined by the court, and
any other claim (whether legal, equitable or otherwise) that is justiciable in the court.
, in relation to proceedings, means costs payable in or in relation to the proceedings, and includes fees, disbursements, expenses and remuneration.
includes tribunal.
means proceedings against a person for an offence (whether summary or indictable), and includes the following:
committal proceedings,
proceedings relating to bail,
proceedings relating to sentence,
proceedings on an appeal against conviction or sentence.
means a claim by a defendant for the grant of relief under section 22.
means a person against whom proceedings are commenced, and includes a person against whom a cross-claim is made.
a function includes perform a duty.
includes power, authority and duty.
includes both trial and interlocutory hearing.
includes any order for the payment of money, including any order for the payment of costs.
means the person to whom a judgment debt is payable.
includes:
any amount payable under a judgment, and
any interest after judgment that is payable on that amount under section 101, and
any other amount payable under rules of court without the need for a judgment.
means the person by whom a judgment debt is payable.
has the same meaning as it has in the Judicial Officers Act 1986.
means:
in relation to the District Court, the jurisdictional limit of that Court within the meaning of the District Court Act 1973, and
in relation to the Local Court sitting in its General Division, the jurisdictional limit of the Local Court when sitting in that Division within the meaning of the Local Court Act 2007, and
in relation to the Local Court sitting in its Small Claims Division, the jurisdictional limit of the Local Court when sitting in that Division within the meaning of the Local Court Act 2007.
[def am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Schs 2, 7, effective 6 July 2009]
means rules of court other than uniform rules.
means a person who is under the age of 18 years.
has the same meaning as claim has in the Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999.
, in relation to a court, includes any registrar or other member of staff employed in the administration of the business of the court, and includes the Judicial Registrar of the District Court.

, in relation to the assessment of legal costs that a court has ordered to be paid, means the basis of assessing costs set out in
section 364(1) and (2)
of the Legal Profession Act 2004.
means the process by which proceedings are commenced, and includes the process by which a cross-claim is made.

means any person who is under a legal incapacity in relation to the conduct of legal proceedings (other than an incapacity arising under
section 4
of the Felons (Civil Proceedings) Act 1981) and, in particular, includes:
a child under the age of 18 years, and
an involuntary patient, a forensic patient or a correctional patient within the meaning of the Mental Health Act 2007, and
a person under guardianship within the meaning of the Guardianship Act 1987, and
a protected person within the meaning of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, and

an incommunicate person, being a person who has such a physical or mental disability that he or she is unable to receive communications, or express his or her will, with respect to his or her property or affairs.
[def am Act 8 of 2007 s 199 and Sch 7[7.2], effective 16 November 2007 ; Act 79 of 2008 s 4 and Sch 3.2, effective 1 March 2009 ; Act 49 of 2009 Sch 2.9[1], effective 1 July 2009]

means a person by whom proceedings are commenced, or on whose behalf proceedings are commenced by a tutor, and includes a person by whom a cross-claim is made or on whose behalf a cross-claim is made by a tutor.
, otherwise than of land, includes custody and power.
means any hearing that is not an interlocutory hearing.
, in relation to a person under legal incapacity, means a tutor appointed to represent the person (whether by the court or otherwise) in accordance with the uniform rules.

means rules made, or taken to have been made, under
section 9
.

means the Uniform Rules Committee established under
section 8
.

means a claim for an award of damages to which
Division 3 of Part 5
of the Workers Compensation Act 1987 applies.
Other words and expressions (for example, rules of court) are defined in the Interpretation Act 1987.
Notes included in this Act do not form part of this Act.
In the notes to this Act, DCR means the District Court Rules 1973, LCR means the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Rules 1988 and SCR means the Supreme Court Rules 1970.

Subject to this section,
Parts 3–9
apply to each court referred to in Schedule 1 in relation to civil proceedings of a kind referred to in that Schedule in respect of that court.

Part 10
applies in relation to civil proceedings in the Supreme Court.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 135 of 2010 s 1 and Sch 6[6.1], effective 4 March 2011]
The uniform rules may exclude any class of civil proceedings from the operation of all or any of the provisions of Parts 3–9.

The Governor may, by regulation, amend or substitute
Schedule 1
.
A regulation under this section may contain provisions consequent on the amendment or substitution of Schedule 1, including:
provisions excluding any class of civil proceedings from the operation of all or any of the provisions of Parts 3–9, and
provisions modifying any specified provision of Parts 3–9, or of any other Act or law, in its application to any class of civil proceedings.
Subject to any such regulation, this Act does not limit the operation of any other Act with respect to the conduct of civil proceedings.
Legislation cited in [s 4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW)
Civil Procedure Act 2005 Parts 3–9, ss 19–153.

(NSW)
Local Court Act 2007 Pt 3.

(NSW)
Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 1, r 1.6.

Parts 3–9
( ss 19–153 ) of the CPA apply to all civil proceedings in the following courts:
Supreme Court of NSW.
District Court of NSW.
Dust Diseases Tribunal of NSW.
Land and Environment Court — all civil proceedings in class 1, 2, 3 or 4.
Industrial Relations Commission (including the Commission in Court Session (the Industrial Court)).

Local Court of NSW — all civil proceedings under
Pt 3
of the Local Court Act 2007 and under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984.

That application is subject to the exclusion of various CPA provisions in relation to proceedings in the Dust Diseases Tribunal and the Small Claims Division of the Local Court. Those exclusions are made in UCPR
r 1.6
and
Sch 1
. The effect of these exclusions is summarised in [1.6.5]–[1.6.15] . See also notes at [1.5.10] ff.
Nothing in this Act or the uniform rules limits the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
Nothing in the uniform rules extends the jurisdiction of any court except to the extent to which this Act expressly so provides.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 6] s 6 Repeals, amendments and savings provisions

p.text:
Each Act and instrument referred to in
Schedule 4
is repealed.
[subs (2) rep Act 120 of 2006 s 4 and Sch 4 , effective 4 December 2006]

Schedule 6
has effect.
Legislation cited in [s 6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW)
Civil Procedure Act 2005 Schedule 6 , 10, cll 5.

(NSW)
Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 42.15.

Schedule 6
provides for the transitional application of the CPA, UCPR, prior legislation and regulations, both in relation to the commencement of the CPA and UCPR in August 2005, and the Courts Legislation Amendment Act 2007. The main transitional provisions relating to proceedings that were current in August 2005 are the complementary provisions in
cll 5
and
10
of Schedule 6.
Clause 5
applies the CPA and UCPR to those proceedings (with a general discretionary dispensation from the requirements of the new rules) and
cl 10
regularises steps taken in those proceedings under the old legislation and rules. Offers of compromise, and the costs issues to which they can give rise, provide fertile circumstances for the exercise of the discretions conferred by these two provisions. Although there may be some awkwardness in speaking of the costs consequences of the uniform rules as a “requirement” from which a dispensation may be given, the obvious purpose of cl 5(2) indicates that semantic infelicity should be ignored:
Atkinson v Zey
[2008] NSWCA 30; BC200801529 at [11]
per Basten JA, Handley AJA agreeing at [23] (dispensation from the requirements of
UCPR r 42.15
in relation to the cost consequences of a District Court offer of compromise).
The Minister is to review this Act to determine whether the policy objectives of the Act remain valid and whether the terms of the Act remain appropriate for securing those objectives.
The review is to be undertaken as soon as possible after the period of 5 years from the date of assent to this Act.
A report on the outcome of the review is to be tabled in each House of Parliament within 12 months after the end of the period of 5 years.
